title: Xanthorrhoea bracteata
text:
Xanthorrhoea bracteata, the shiny grasstree, is a species of grasstree of the genus "<a href="Xanthorrhoea">Xanthorrhoea</a>" <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. It is one of many species described by Scottish botanist <a href="Robert%20Brown%20%28botanist%2C%20born%201773%29">Robert Brown</a>.
Description.
The shiny grasstree grows no discernible trunk, though it may have multiple crowns. The leaves are 40–110 cm long and 1.5–3 mm wide. The flower spike is usually less than a third the length of the <a href="scape%20%28botany%29">scape</a>, which is very thin (4–9 mm diameter). The small white flowers are about 3 mm wide and grow in tight clusters, appearing between January and February. The fruit is a capsule containing round, slightly flattened seeds.
Distribution and habitat.
The grasstree is endemic to Tasmania and is known only from a small number of sites between <a href="Narawntapu%20National%20Park">Narawntapu National Park</a> in the <a href="Asbestos%20Range">Asbestos Range</a> and Mount William in the north-eastern corner of the State. It grows on sandy, coastal <a href="heath">heath</a> soils, which are often acidic and waterlogged.
Conservation.
The species is considered to be <a href="endangered%20species">Endangered</a> under the Australian <a href="Environment%20Protection%20and%20Biodiversity%20Conservation%20Act%201999">Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999</a>, and <a href="vulnerable%20species">vulnerable</a> under the Tasmanian <a href="Threatened%20Species%20Protection%20Act%201995">Threatened Species Protection Act 1995</a>. Threats include infection by "<a href="Phytophthora%20cinnamomi">Phytophthora cinnamomi</a>", land clearance, inappropriate burning regimes and foliage harvesting.
References.
